31.description: The highlight of our trip to Chicago was our visit to Jazz Showcase.  KT had asked if we would like to see some jazz while in town so we did a little investigation and ended up at Jazz Showcase based on its reputation and the artists playing that weekend.  We happened to be there for the Ari Brown Quintet and found enough examples of his playing on YouTube to know what we would be hearing.This review is for Jazz Showcase and not for Ari Brown, but I must say I would go back to hear him and his group any time.  At least on the night we were there they played great straight-ahead hard bop, it was perfect for our group.  We all liked it.  I would like to see him come down to St Louis to Jazz at the Bistro.  I was surprised the place was not packed full for this local talent.  I hope he is appreciated in Chicago.We are regulars at Jazz at the Bistro and found Jazz Showcase to be similar.  It is a little larger, seating and viewing is still excellent and it remains an intimate venue.  It is a listening room with drinks service, rather than a nightclub.  I have bookmarked Jazz Showcase to watch the artists that they have coming.  I would not rule out an occasional drive to Chicago for more.  Places like this keep Jazz accessible to those of us who prefer the intimate places to the concert halls and who are not night club people.   I also liked that they have Sunday afternoon family friendly matinees.  This is a great place for jazz.

34.description: A gem for the south loop. I usually come here when Rajiv Halim plays.The jazz acts the play here are all good.There usually is a cover like $10 but it is worth it. I look at covers this way. It's like you are paying for the music and it helps the place book the talent plus its like you are paying a service fee to help the establishment keep rif raff out. Like people who get into fights, are not ready to be outside their house and other crap like that. This way you are just with people who are classy or want to be out.I first saw Rajiv Halim play at The Drake last year. I like his sax act and how he mixes it up.youtube.com/watch?v=aVG-…He and I are not related. The reason I bring it up is because he plays at this place a few times a year.This is not a dingy jazz place. A good place to see some of Chicago's home grown jazz talent.check the schedule. if you are a live jazz person, you will be tempted to stop on by

16.description: Fabulous!!!  Cheap cover and a great performance last night.  I especially appreciate that you don't have to meet a drink/food minimum here.  I am so happy I happened upon this place.

13.description: The highlight of our trip to Chicago was our visit to Jazz Showcase.  KT had asked if we would like to see some jazz while in town so we did a little investigation and ended up at Jazz Showcase based on its reputation and the artists playing that weekend.  We happened to be there for the Ari Brown Quintet and found enough examples of his playing on YouTube to know what we would be hearing.This review is for Jazz Showcase and not for Ari Brown, but I must say I would go back to hear him and his group any time.  At least on the night we were there they played great straight-ahead hard bop, it was perfect for our group.  We all liked it.  I would like to see him come down to St Louis to Jazz at the Bistro.  I was surprised the place was not packed full for this local talent.  I hope he is appreciated in Chicago.We are regulars at Jazz at the Bistro and found Jazz Showcase to be similar.  It is a little larger, seating and viewing is still excellent and it remains an intimate venue.  It is a listening room with drinks service, rather than a nightclub.  I have bookmarked Jazz Showcase to watch the artists that they have coming.  I would not rule out an occasional drive to Chicago for more.  Places like this keep Jazz accessible to those of us who prefer the intimate places to the concert halls and who are not night club people.   I also liked that they have Sunday afternoon family friendly matinees.  This is a great place for jazz.

11.description: I want to give it 5 stars but they don't take care of the bathroom between shows and charge $1 extra (separate line item in the bill and everything) for ice in your drink...just petty stuff for a $30 cover charge. The mystic and space saves it but maybe this is just a preview of the post Joe Segal regime.

39.description: This is the best place for jazz in Chicago (all respect given to The Green Mill and Andy's). The atmosphere harkens back to a bygone day of live music. I've been here on several occasions, and have yet to be disappointed with the groups they bring in.My most recent trip to the Showcase was on NYE to hear the Roy Hargrove quintet. It was absolutely my ideal rendition of what NYE should be like: good music, a drink or two, and good people.

37.description: A great Chicago classic place for jazz.

0.description: Wow!! Coworker and I wanted to celebrate our Christmas break. We wanted to go out to listen to some live jazz. Ive heard so much about the jazz showcase and I didn't want to miss the opportunity to see Rodger Glasper Trio.  People came everywhere from out of town, south side, Wheaton and Highland Park. Show was sold out!! We were lucky enough to get standing tickets by the bar. Great music, Great view, Great environment and Wonderful staff. No matter where you seated it was a great seat. Drinks, the bartender allowed you sample couple of choices. Wow!! Never had a bartender do that before. I recommend this for a date night, meet up with friends and for the ones who just loves great music. The crowd was diverse in ages, race and sizes of people. Before or afterward you can dined at Bar Louie's. That located on the corner.

38.description: Strolled in late (11pm) on a Friday to catch some jazz only to find out that there was maybe fifteen minutes of the final set left. Really? In Chicago? I was surprised to learn this. Either way the door guy was cool and let us catch the last little bit. The layout is pretty straight forward, bar in the back, tables and chairs, stage, bathrooms to either side of the stage. Tip - if your evening is still in progress after the Showcase is done, Buddy's is right around the corner and still going.

51.description: Saw the Heath Brothers Quartet here on a recent Sunday night -- fantastic, these guys were great. As to the JS - great room, got there early, had good seats. $25 cover charge, cash only. Drinks not cheap but well made - $8 for a Jack Daniels & ginger ale, but tasty. Staff friendly. Waitress attentive but not hovering. Sound system good. Ambiance good - lots of photos and posters; sound system first rate. No food here, so if you're hungry eat before you go. Their web site says "The only food here is the olive in your martini."Will absolutely go back next time in Chicago.

27.description: As a huge jazz fan, I was very excited when I stumbled across this gem near my hotel. This is an exceptional place! The vibe is fantastic, it's the 2nd oldest jazz club in the country and the music on the night I went was stellar. Bartender was a bit of a tool, but the waitresses were awesome and friendly. A must see place if you are a jazz fan visiting Chicago!

32.description: One of the best venues for jazz in the country, hands down! They also boast a reasonable cover charge, especially for big names that play there.

54.description: I love good  jazz.  I love intimate venues for live music.  I love jazz photos/art.  I love history.  And this place has it all.  During the week, the cover is only 10 bucks.  If you are hungry, you can stop by Bar Louie next door and either eat there before the start of a show, or you can bring your food.  The drinks are reasonably priced.  The last time we went, we saw a great band that had not performed together in over 22 years.  They were actually quite good and I personally appreciated them returning to their passion after taking a break to "take care of life" as they put it.  One of the singers was particularly good and gave a great performance.  I took off one star because the few times I have been, the place has been quite cold and the seating isn't especially comfortable to me.  But everything else is 5 stars.  Hope to go back next weekend to hear Willie Pickens...check out his band if you haven't - awesome!!

48.description: Great little jazz spot in printers row.  You can see great music here almost any night of the week.  The drink list is on the basic side, but it's good enough if you are here for the music.  This venue has great feel, and more than a little bit of history.

44.description: I"m not exactly a jazz connoisseur, but I knew over the holidays I wanted to go to a nice relaxed jazz spot and I found Jazz Showcase.  So glad I did, I went over the holidays to see Roy Hargrove quintent, and it was awesome!!  A nice intimate venue, very relaxed (even with a packed house) and great location in Printer's Row.  We had "VIP" seating ($45) but given the size of the venue, I cant say that there are any bad seats.  I cant comment on the mixed drinks, but the waitstaff was moving briskly.  I arrived a few minutes into the set, after dinner (which I had with me)...and the guy at the door just asked if I was going to be eating that I open things before I went in (?)...if I was still hungry, I would have really appreciated that lol.  Great venue, and awesome talent....oh, and I appreciated how diverse the crowd was (both age and ethnicity) which was another plus for me.The only other venue for jazz I've been to in Chicago was Green Mill, and I'd definitely visit Jazz Showcase before making the long trek up north.

24.description: I went to Robert Glasper showcase last night and it was absolutely wonderful! His performance was flawless and the band left nothing to be desired. I ordered French martinis which were the best I've had in a very long time. The ambiance matched the energy of the crowd..... Pure Dopeness!!

7.description: Seriously, why consider going anywhere else?I went here on a my first weekend living in Chicago and I was blown away at how good it was.  The music was sooooooo gooood!!!  They mixed up the show between high energy jazz, smooth and sultry, and finally, classic jazz.  Each instrument was given a solo so you really got a taste of the various personal styles.   I was actually sad that I couldn't record the music, but it means I'll definitely have to return.  This is easily my new date spot, and a place I hope to go once a week.  The venue is also the best I've seen of dedicated jazz clubs in town.  I love the couches, the vintage pictures and advertisements, and the fact that every seat has a good view of the stage without standing spectators obstructing your enjoyment.

49.description: This is a great place to unwind after another crazy day at work.  The staff is friendly and the servers are attentive.  It's a very laid-back atmosphere (get there when you get there-- you're always welcome).  I often go by myself or with friends.  It's pretty large, but it feels intimate thanks to the candlelight at every table.  It has comfy seating spread throughout.  It is too bad more young people (or more people generally) don't frequent it.  The photographs suggest this was the spot to be some years back.  It has a great variety of shows and features some really talented musicians.  Enjoy!

40.description: I went here recently and had a fabulous time, and am looking forward to going back. I will be getting in more of the Jazz Showcase this Spring/Summer.

53.description: I've been going to here since they were at the Blackstone Hotel.  This location in Printers Row is only 2nd to the Blackstone location.  The ambience and setting is perfect for a jazz environment.  Wayne and Joe Segal know how to present the perfect jazz venue.

30.description: Went for the Jazz and got a nice dose, great music, nice atmosphere, and Joe the owner was there greeting everybody at the door.  There was a show at 8PM and another at 10PM, wish it was one long show with more than one band.

46.description: Pleasantly surprised. I'm not much of a jazz fan but wanted to let out-of-town friend experience true Chicago. The space is nice and not as crowded as Green Mill. The atmosphere was also more laid back (nobody shushing and frowning if you can't resist the urge to whisper). Cover was $20 when I went, didn't know if the artist was famous but I enjoyed the music and had a great time. Recommended!

1.description: I came here for New Years Eve and was supper excited to ring in the new year with some jazz.The music was wonderful, but we left with a sour taste in our mouth when one of the managers/bartenders shushed us! We were sitting at the bar, quite far from the band itself, so we really didn't see any harm in some chit chat while the music was playing. I'd love to come back and try it out on a regular night, as this night was just A-OK.

55.description: We came for a late night 10pm after dinner show, and had a no problem finding a seat. That was pretty much the only good thing encountered. We had to pay $25 dollars per person to get in. Expecting to get a good show we decided to pay and walked in. The service was terrible, but that is to be expected in a jazz bar. And the show? Well ... for 45 minutes of music and the musicians deciding what they are going to play next I can say there was barely a show. And definitely not worth $25 dollars. So when you decide to spontaneously go here make sure you check who is playing and if anything arrive to the early 8pm show.

9.description: Went here on a Sunday afternoon and enjoyed the space and live jazz music. Beer is cheap. Only $5-7 but I don't recommend getting a cocktail. The bartender didn't know how to make the most basic of drinks. Parking is only $5 so I recommend driving and parking - don't drink and drive though

26.description: This is a classic Chicago jazz nightclub.  Nothing fancy...just tables, drinks, and great music.  We saw Paul Molinaro and loved him and the place.

25.description: A Grown Folks Jazz Club - lol. Finally got my butt to this Fantastic and Legendary Club and it's ashame I didn't stop in much sooner, like years ago. Jazz Showcase is A Gold Standard in what a Jazz Club should be. All about the music and you the fan enjoying it. It's a Small and Cozy club. Excellent, Professional and Courteous Service from the host to the servers. I saw Robert Glasper Trio's 1st show in 7yrs together and it was OUTSTANDING. Seating is great and I don't think there's a bad view in he place. Heck, if you're lucky, you might be able to get a spot on the couch located on stage. Yes, while the band's performing you're sitting on the stage. I can't say enough GREAT things about the service. I felt like I was being welcomed home. Very friendly people and looking forward to returning. It's located just south of downtown Chicago, so if you're an out of towner, it's a short cab ride or long walk depending on where you're staying. Make it your business to see shows at the club.

12.description: I agree with everyone that the jazz performances are wonderful, however, I do wish the owner would consider A better cocktail menu to ensure his cocktails are the same caliber as the performances.I have been to the Jazz Showcase several times, however I am always disappointed by the quality of the mixed drinks served. The bartenders are very nice and courteous but the mixers are always flat and the drinks are watered down. I live in the neighborhood and would go more often if the complete experience was better.

59.description: Jazz Showcase was one of the stops on the Jazz Tour  - definitely a must-visit for the future. I loved the spacious and old-school glamorous feel of the hall.

21.description: We had a great experience because we had a private pre-party but I was disappointed the band started an hour later than scheduled time which means I had to miss most of the show!

17.description: This venue is an awesome place to enjoy jazz in Chicago.  Parking is very convenient with a lot right next door and a security person to watch over your ride.  Inside the staff were extremely nice to us and showed us to a table.  We had to share because it is crowded, but this was not a problem.  Drinks are served at the table, but you can also bring in someone under 18 as long as you are a parent or guardian.  I did not see any food options.

10.description: Went on a Thursday on a date This was a great spot I never head of Great atmosphere . Lots of history and great music 20 to get ... A little high price for only 90 min set , but I think worth it

5.description: I'm not a huge Jazz music guy so this is coming from the perspective of a newb just having a good time. Went here with a jazz enthusiast and she loved it. The band was really talented and easy to listen to. Drink menu had a lot to offer from cocktails to beers. Venue had plenty of seating available. One could sit right in front of the band or in the back by the bar. Good place to bring a date. Dim lit atmosphere with a spotlight on the mainstage. It was a fresh experience.

3.description: A fantastic venue for live jazz. Just don't order the High Society cocktail, it tastes like Robitussin cough medicine.

35.description: I stopped in to listen to a set during the Annual Jazz Pub Crawl.... It was love at first sight. I found it to be the perfect setting.  Nice, clean, dimly lit, lots of windows, an actual stage and great acoustics. It's a nice spot for date night or have a cocktail or three after dinner. The place has both traditional tables and high tops. There is also seating at the bar. If I had to guess, the place comfortably holds 150 people.

19.description: I brought a friend here for his birthday and the experience was AMAZING. The venue is intimate and the space is medium sized but can fill up pretty quickly so get there early. The Jazz was great and I was ready to come back again before I even left lol I will be back here for sure!

28.description: A music venue closest to matching our image of Chicago's jazz history.  We'll just try going over and paying cover next time, but on this occasion the artist (Pat Martino) was such a talent, and it was our first time, and we wanted to be sure to try seats right up front, so we opted to purchase seats ahead on line.  Unfortunately messed up and booked the early show when we meant to book the late and didn't realize until we were at the door.  Must have been the kind owner, at the desk, who admitted us graciously despite our error.  Cozy but roomy space with multiple seating style options and more an intimate concert space with drinks than a club with the music as background - great. Husband loved being up close on comfy little couch; I enjoy bar stool height seats and would try the back another time.  Either way, will return.

45.description: The venue was wonderful!!  Small yet intimate with great sound.  Saw the Maurice Brown Quintet and they were outstanding!!!!  Very nice hostess and we had a great time!!  Will definitely return!!!

33.description: Enjoyed my night here. It is as advertised.Showed up slightly late and was sat at a couch near the stage on the side of the room - it was actually great.The music was fine and the band was quite humorous hosts.  If you are looking for jazz in Chicago, I would look to come here.

43.description: Great entertainment,convenient parking,we saw Ravi Coltrane , great seating, altogether great night!!

2.description: We went to see Joey De Francesco, arguably one of the greatest B3 organ players ever (per my date).  If you are a jazz enthusiastic you will love the place.   They frequent live musicians each week.  The owner went over the schedule, and I wished I lived in the area.  There was not a bad seat in the house.  Good vibes, good music.  Apparently on Sunday, you can bring your children to a matinee so they can experience real music. :) Our Uber driver was unfamiliar with the area.  Thankfully we saw the BIG Jazz Showcase sign before he put us out at any one of several abandoned buildings. SMH.The drinks are expensive, but it doesn't matter if you come from the music.  After looking at the other reviews, I didn't even try to go to the bathroom.

18.description: We had a great experience because we had a private pre-party but I was disappointed the band started an hour later than scheduled time which means I had to miss most of the show!

41.description: I love this place for world renowned artists, but have to point out a few negatives , which they should really work on if they want to survive.  The cocktails are horrible.  They serve the cheapest alcohol in your cocktail (and it's not inexpensive).  Even after asking for a specific rum, they still gave me the cheap stuff.  One of the enjoyments when listening to live music is to relax with a good drink.  Also, their seating is back breaking.  They have small tables with hard wooden chairs that are so uncomfortable, that you can't sit very long.  They have a few cushy love seats, but they are always taken.  I really hope that Joe makes the changes with the bar and can get more comfortable seating.  These two negatives can make the entire experience unpleasant.  People like to "relax" while enjoying live music.

52.description: Loved it. Looked up things to do around Chicago before traveling for a conference. Walked over on a Monday evening from the Palmer House, was charged 1/2 the entrance because I showed up at least 20 minutes into the hr. The 7 & 7 I was served was tasty, stronger than not, which is to say perfect for some 20-something in search of a dark, beat room to hear music and wander mentally. The band I saw perform were 5 different folks ranging a good 23 years in age, 8 inches in hair (facial or head), and several shades of pigment. Their music was awesome, and so were their solos. The transitions from many to one instrument were graceful, gracious. I'd like to go back already.

50.description: Nice and quaint place that has good blues/jazz music. We went on a Saturday night and it wasn't busy. Cover charge was $20. Good entertaining music with a good crowd. Bar makes good  drinks and the bartender was very friendly. We lucked out with good seats next to the bar with a great view on a high table (recommended so you don't have somebody's head in your way). A good alternative to the usual clubs.

4.description: My Bestie invite me out to see Robert Glasper in concert. Amazing very low key and mature atmosphere. The whole experience was grown sexy and relaxing.I felt so relaxed after a long week at work. Nice music wine and awesome ambience.Well be back for another concert.

6.description: After living in the south loop for 6 years my wife and I finally made it to the Jazz Showcase to see the Roy Hargrove Quintet.  A fantastic venue for live jazz, the band was groovin' and put on a great show!  The show seemed to be sold out, as the venue was full, but there was not a bad seat in the house. And they have some couches, in different areas of the seating area.The wait staff was busy before and during the show serving cocktails, service was a little slow but the two servers had a full house so I can't expect them to work faster than they did. They were hustling to accommodate all the customers.Previous reviews mentioned the bathroom cleanliness.  I did use the restroom, and did not see the same issues as previous posters.Drink prices are actually very reasonable comparative to other places in the loop. Beer $5-7, and cocktails $7-12.Not sure why we waited so long to actually come here, but will definitely be back regularly now!

22.description: I recently went to Jazz Showcase with a group of friends. I had never heard of the place, but was blown away by how much fun it was! Good music, good alcohol selection, and great atmosphere. The location is in a strange area. Safe, but strange.I have lived in the South Loop for a while and am only a 12 minute walk away from this place (it is ~10 minutes from the corner of Michigan and Roosevelt). Now that I know Jazz Showcase exists, I will definitely be going back!

15.description: I recently went to Jazz Showcase with a group of friends. I had never heard of the place, but was blown away by how much fun it was! Good music, good alcohol selection, and great atmosphere. The location is in a strange area. Safe, but strange.I have lived in the South Loop for a while and am only a 12 minute walk away from this place (it is ~10 minutes from the corner of Michigan and Roosevelt). Now that I know Jazz Showcase exists, I will definitely be going back!

57.description: One of the jazz club gems in Chicago. The talent is top notch and the nostalgic decor takes you back to the golden days of jazz. The chairs aren't the most comfortable for an extended stay.

20.description: This venue is an awesome place to enjoy jazz in Chicago.  Parking is very convenient with a lot right next door and a security person to watch over your ride.  Inside the staff were extremely nice to us and showed us to a table.  We had to share because it is crowded, but this was not a problem.  Drinks are served at the table, but you can also bring in someone under 18 as long as you are a parent or guardian.  I did not see any food options.

36.description: Like it a lot, think it's defly one of the top 3 in Chicago (on par with Greenmill, Andy's).

14.description: Had a wonderful holiday treat to visit Joe Segal's (new) dogs and to see the fantastic Roy Hargrove Quartet on January 2. Had not been to venue since before it moves from the historic Blackstone and was pleasantly surprised. While it lacked the retro-cool ambience of the original, it was comfy enough (get VIP seating if possible), some former staff were on hand, jazz enthusiasts were aglow in the intimate setting and the smell of stale cigar and cigarette smoke was gone (yay!).For Chicago to have the unique vintage it possesses with jazz, why are there so few intimate venues today in which to enjoy world-class artists such as Hargrove? Fortunately, not only does the Showcase still make this possible but affordable. Additionally, my party ordered three premium cocktails for under $20 and convenient parking was only $5 - in the South Loop!Thank you Jazz Showcase for keeping it real and keeping it ALIVE.By the way, Hargrove and Co. were ON FIRE during the last show of the evening and he even treated us to a vocal rendition of "Never Let Me Go". It was stirringly emotional and captive.

28.description: Really great food and empty! Great place!

1.description: Nostalgic. Dinner their with friends and family and forgotten how cool a venue and view SSCC had.The staff was friendly but needed some prompting. Food was surprisingly well prepared and tasty (a bit heavy handed in the salt) but overall a good start to a great evening.  The venue is in need of a good scrub (bathrooms not well maintained) and building needed a power wash.  South Shore Cultural Center is a Southside jewel. I hope to go more often.

9.description: Wanted to love this to support the culinary institute students.Great parts:  the food was delicious at the Sunday brunch.  Lots of meat.  Some of the best sliced turkey breast I've ever had.Not-so-great parts:  the servers were not good.  After being seated by the hostess, no one came to say "hi" or bring water until about 15 minutes later.  Once she came over, she was nice but had little tableside manner.  She took my son's plate mid-bite (with several bites left.)  She poured my coffee into the wrong cup.  She reached over us instead of serving at our right, etc.  I wouldn't worry about this, but she's supposedly learning how to serve in a fine restaurant, as well as how to work in the kitchen.  Actually, our server told us she'd graduated and had gotten a real job there.  Maybe she was just having a bad day.I'm not a complaining customer, but there were so many issues (gnats b/c patio doors were open) that they gave us one brunch gratis.  That was really nice.We will go back, because, again, we want the students to succeed.  And the free brunch helped.  But they need to refine the service a bit.

29.description: Just did holiday brunch with Santa.  Having had a pretty nice dinner here in the past, I was surprised by today's brunch.  Let me begin by saying that the Parrot Cage is a gorgeous room with tons of charm, a real gem on the south shore.  It should also be noted that it is part of a culinary school, so the food is prepared and served by students.  The end result is a mostly fine dining experience at a reasonable price. Admittedly, I walk in the door not expecting the same treatment or cuisine that I would expect at a 3-4 star restaurant downtown and everything works out just fine. That being said, today's buffet style brunch was awful. Our server never asked us if we wanted any drinks, we had to flag him down to order coffee and never got any refills. As for the food, let me begin by saying that I LOVE brunch buffets, however only the carved beef was up to snuff here.  Well roasted, albeit flavorless. The rest of the fare could either be described as bland or dry... salmon cakes, fried chicken, macaroni and cheese, greens, potatoes, bacon and sausage.  Yes, that was everything. ANY type of sauces paired with ANY of the buffet items would have gone a long way to save this brunch.  I can safely say that the quality of the buffet items was below what I would expect from "Chef's Kitchen" or similar grocery store hot deli counter carryout food.  We did NOT try the omelet station or waffle.  One dessert was offered, a vat of soggy peach & strawberry cobbler that our toddler enjoyed.We left feeling ripped-off, disappointed and hungry... which is a first for me at a buffet brunch.

23.description: I'd give Parrot Cage one star because it's quite lovely in decor, and comfortable with good jazz in the background.  That being said, the food was disappointing considering it is run by the Washburn Culinary Institute.  The prices are reasonable, and we tried the prix fixe menu for $30.  The house martini was way too sweet & Grey Goose couldn't be tasted,  crab appetizer used snow crab, but menu said jumbo lump crab meat, and was bland, the fritto de mare had slightly tough calamari, the salmon entree was overcooked with dry edges & sorely lacking in Moroccan spices, the lamb chops were ok.  My frustration peaked when dessert arrived with peach cobbler from canned peaches!  Wait staff seemed unconcerned...My dinner companion packed her dessert to go only to arrive home and find a fly in it!  Not planning a return, and such a shame!!

5.description: A beautiful little dining room in the clubhouse of the old South Shore Country Club that offers a Supper Club menu of meat and fish.Being a training ground for cooking school students the food was well prepared and hit the appropriate notes. The Caesar was a simple presentation of dressing, croutons, and parmesan laid over a bed of smoky grilled romaine. The Tilapia Entrée consisted of a large filet laid over a bed of fresh green beans and drizzled with lobster sauce and tiny bits of tomato. The beans were firm without tasting raw and paired well with the sauce. The filet was pan seared to melt in your mouth perfection. A large piece of Tres Leche Chocolate Cake had just the right amount of milky goodness and ordered with Vanilla Ice Cream that was presented in a chocolate cup with a thick bottom, a decadent treat! The coffee was delicious as well.The servers were in training as well, very friendly and mostly on top of their duties. The salad arriving before our drinks was the only misstep. The dinner roll server came by twice and the host checked in to see how we were doing, a nice touch.The bill arrived with a scholarship charge of 5 percent added. This is more of a contribution to the students tuition fund than a gratuity so a regular tip is necessary, if not required. The additional gratuity must be paid in cash.Overall a pleasant dining experience in a historic setting. You will leave satisfied and feel good about helping the students on their path to success.

31.description: Best kept secret in south shore.I love it and everything on the menu.The Sunday brunch is the best deal in town.

25.description: Not a huge reviewer, but had to comment on this place. First of all, I've been going to the South Shore Cultural Center since I was a little boy. I spent many a year in their summer camp program. I though it was an awesome place then, and I think the facility is an awesome place now. The views (when it's not pouring rain, like last night) are wonderful and the overall atmosphere is just great.With that said, the Parrot Cage received 4 stars from me. The food was excellent (I had the Pan Seared Tilapia), our server was nice and attentive and even apologetic when my Aunt's fish was a little too spicy for her tastes and couldn't be redone for her. She even went the extra mile to not charge my Aunt for the drink that she had.  My biggest complaint however, is that it took what felt like 5 years for us to get our food after we ordered. I never knew it took that long to cook what was a majority of fish dishes. However, the plating of each dish in my opinion was really nice.I've read a few harsh reviews about the restaurant here and the only think I can think of is that because they are students, maybe they rotate out and you don't have the same people there every year, because everyone was pleasant from the moment we walked into the door to the minute we walked out.

12.description: A beautiful nostalgic restaurant where the Washburne Culinary Institute students prepare the meals. The star of the experience is the restaurant and the location being right on Lake Michigan; while dining my mind wondered what really went on here during the country club years.  The food was delicious, and the service was polite. I would recommend this place to anyone who is looking for something different or romantic and after the meal why not take a walk around the grounds if you visit on the weekend you will most likely see a wedding or a reception taking place. Like Corinne G. said this place really is a hidden gem!

21.description: The food was excellent but the setting upstaged it.  There were six of us and the staff obligingly set up a round table for us in the corner right next to the window, where we (well, those of us not facing west) could see out the floor-to-ceiling window into the park and toward the nearby lake).  I hadn't been in the building in nearly 20 years and was thrilled to see that the weird green/gilt/oxblood color scheme from the 1980s had been replaced with something warm and cream/peachy. The prix fixe was a great deal, and they were gracious about sending us home with leftovers (there was a lot of food).  The service was friendly but rather slow in parts: one of my hosts had to step out for 45 minutes to deliver one of the guests to a nocturnal janitorial gig, because the whole thing took about an hour longer than we had expected.  So I wouldn't suggest it for a tightly scheduled pre-theater date, but if you just want to hang out and relax, it's great.  (I suspect the martinis were rather strong, which may have contributed to our lack of ambition to get out of there any time soon.)Transportation note:  The place is practically next door to the South Shore stop on the Metra Electric line, which originates in the Loop.  It's kind of a long and lonely walk at night up the drive through the park from the street--a legacy of the country club mentality from when this place was built--but well lit, and pretty.BTW I assume the name is in honor of the green monk parakeets that are all over the south side.  Kind of a dumb and insensitive name, considering that these characters' ancestors apparently escaped from some pet-store shipment, and now live happy, loud and free (squawk).

16.description: Always good, well presented food.Excellent service from wait staff.We also enjoy the low background music and the decor.

17.description: I chose this restaurant because of its name (The Parrot Cage ... ridiculous and awesome?) and because it's part of a culinary school, which usually leads to good and cheaper results. Also BYOB. ($5 corkage fee)The setting is amazing. It's in the South Shore Cultural Center, which is right on Lake Michigan and a beautiful old building. It's a bit of a hike from the North side, but worth it.The service is a little slow (as is the crowd in general, lots of older people), but the food is great and the staff is so friendly and nice. And it's always fun to support students. They start with this delicious seed-bread? I'm not great with tastes (or memory - it's been almost three years since I've been there), but it was bread with some seeds in it or something. Whatever, it was great. Since I'm boring, I always ordered the salmon, but that was GREAT and obviously I liked it enough that I continued to return there and order it.It's also a fun date place.

10.description: I loved, loved, loved this place! I love the fact that it is housed in the beautiful and historically rich South Shore Cultural Center for starters. As others have mentioned, this is truly a hidden gem on the South Side. I also loved that the place is run by the Washburne(sp?) students. I think it's an excellent concept and you get to witness first-hand these students developing their craft.As for the food, excellent. I went on a Wednesday with the prix fixe menu, which was a steal. I had the grilled caesar salad that was done just right and the lamb for my entree, which was so tender it almost fell off of the bone! My dining partners also enjoyed their meals. One of them had the pork chop that was so huge it was almost unreal. And, despite its size, she also said that it was done to perfection! It's a classy place and the dining room was packed with a diverse crowd, with multiple people who found the place pleasurable enough to celebrate their birthdays there that night.  I will definitely be back to try their brunch buffet. I highly recommend this place to anyone who enjoys a fine dining experience!

11.description: Hidden gem!I would never have heard of the Parrot Cage if not for searching for Wednesday prix fixe specials on Yelp. The restaurant definitely suffers from a lack of marketing... We couldn't even find any signs on the outside of the South Shore Cultural Center telling visitors that the Parrot Cage was inside, so we weren't positive we were in the right place until we walked in. I had never heard of the place before seeing it on Yelp. The South Shore Cultural Center is a gem itself! I found out that it's where President Barack Obama and Michelle held their wedding reception, and it is listed on the historic register. The marble stairs, chandeliers, and architectural details are stunning!Upon entering, we were sure glad we found the Parrot Cage! We were there for about an hour and a half, and the entire time, there was only one other table of two diners there. With the quality of the food and the beauty of the atmosphere, it should be filled. There are very few restaurants with a view of the lakefront, and the food holds it own as well. The goat-cheese flan alone is worth the trip! My husband also raved about his jambalaya. He finished the etouffée entree in short order, pronouncing it "very good," and I also enjoyed my crab-encrusted catfish. For dessert, my husband said the peach cobbler was among the best he'd had, and my banana bread pudding was good as well, although just a bit on the dry side. Maybe more sauce would have helped? We also enjoyed a couple of the signature cocktails, the Parrot Martini and the Pineapple Martini.  Overall, I would give the food and service and solid 4 stars, while the beauty of the location rates a 5. We will make an effort to return... the Wednesday prix fixe is a great value!

26.description: What a unique and interesting dining experience!The Parrot Cage restaurant is the kitchen and stomping grounds of a culinary school, but you hardly notice and the food and service are wonderful!  The restaurant is located in the gorgeous South Shore Cultural center/country club that I now want to research.We were seated at a table with a lovely view of the lake and our server greeted us quickly.  The wine list is small, but all of the glasses are offered for $6 and the bottles are all $24.  The menu includes a wide variety of items and you can choose anything you want for the prix fixe menu, which is $30 (we lucked out and got it for $19 because there was a special promotion).We started with the shrimp and grits and the crawfish soup.  The soup was hearty and spicy and the grits were TO DIE FOR.  If this place was not so hard for us to get to than I would return often for these.  For our entrees we had the salmon and the steak.  The salmon was nicely prepared, however the steak had a lot of fat on it.  For dessert we had the banana bread pudding and the cookie sundae.  The cookie was impressive as it was freshly baked in a hot skillet, however it did not taste quite as good as it looked.Overall, I would give the food three stars, however I bumped it up to four as the venue was just so impressive.The check is a little strange here are they charge an automatic 10% gratuity.  I added an additional 10% on top of this (to make it 20%) but then when I asked my server about it, she said that the 10% gratuity was actually for a scholarship and did not go to her so I am not sure if you are supposed to add 20% on top of the 10% already included....THE FACTS:Prix-fixe is $30 on Wednesday and Thursday night (anything on the menu)Corkage is $5There is a 10% gratuity/scholarship added to your bill

27.description: Food is great!, service is great!Ate here twice, once takeout and second time I dined in. LOVED IT!!!!!Hidden Gem

35.description: I'm really hesistant to write about this place because I've always considered the South Shore Cultural Center one of those little secrets to be kept between those in the know.  Only in the last few years has the parrot cage been added to this lovely place, which is the setting for the practical application for students of Washburn's Culinary program.  The cream of butternut squash was great.  I thought the reduction served with a pepper crusted filet mignon was fantastic and the Jerk Chicken was nothing short of scrumptious.  Additionally  I enjoyed the malbec they had available to accompany my dinner.  The food was sometimes a bit salty, and the students will have to slightly improve their table side manner but both of those criticisms are meant more as constructive advice rather than a negativism.  I will come back here... and even though it was shown on "Check Please," lets try to keep this place on the low.

0.description: Sunday was my first time at the Parrot Cage, although I had it on my list as a place to go.  Four of us enjoyed the excellent selections, the lovely decor and the reasonable price for a Sunday buffet.  I was called the night before and advised that they did not yet have their liquor license, but would  serve wine if we brought it.  I brought Proseco and the waitress was lovely to bring out the champagne glasses and pour our orange juice to mix our mimosas!We were able to tour the ballrooms.  It is a beautiful location and the space is beautiful.  The old South Shore Country Club which is now owned by the Chicago Park District.  Seeing the building itself (at the end of the lake shore bike trail) is great fun, and the restaurant is just the icing on the cake.  I am looking forward to an evening dinner.

20.description: Hidden gem!I would never have heard of the Parrot Cage if not for searching for Wednesday prix fixe specials on Yelp. The restaurant definitely suffers from a lack of marketing... We couldn't even find any signs on the outside of the South Shore Cultural Center telling visitors that the Parrot Cage was inside, so we weren't positive we were in the right place until we walked in. The marble stairs, chandeliers, and architectural details are stunning!Upon entering, we were sure glad we found the Parrot Cage!
